resources.string: This isn\’t a camera, you can\’t take pictures. Move it around and you\’ll find activities to do in your area.
Pull the handle or shake the phone to have an activity selected for you.
First select an activity by pulling the handle!
Click to select a local option (if any are below):
Choose Jackpot if you would like to have an activity chosen for you, choose Customize if you want to make your own selection, or Find Something Nearby to see activities in your immediate area.
Now that you have selected an activity, choose a local option (if any are listed below, every activity does not have a local option). Then save your activity.
This is the last step! Once you\'re done here either go and do your chosen activity or save it for later.
Here you can spin the wheels to automatically create an activity, you can keep spinning until you find an activity you like.
Here you can learn more about this positive activities and why they are good for your mental health!
Here we walk you through three or four steps to customize an activity that sounds interesting to you! Scroll the options with your finger or pull the lever.
Here you can change application settings, click to toggle items on and off.
You can rate each part of an activity. The higher the rating, the more likely they are to show up in your jackpot!

These are all the activities you have previously saved. If you click on one, you can navigate or call to the local option (if available), invite others to join you and/or post the activity to your social media, and rate your enjoyment of the activity.
This tab allows you to learn more about the app, change your contact list preferences, change your activity preferences, and change application settings.
Deselect all activities you don\’t enjoy.
These are all the contacts you have in your phone, deselect contacts that you do not wish to have as options when selecting activities.
Do not show this pop-up again
The Augmented Reality portion of this application is not compatible with Accessibility features for the visually impaired.
Before you can select activities, you need to setup your contacts.\r\n\r\nVisit the setup screen by clicking Settings at the top.
Your GPS is currently disabled. Please enable GPS before using this feature.
I\m Sue, your setup coach. I will help you through the setup of this application.

First, let me introduce you to the Positive Activities app. Participating in fun, positive activities helps improve the overall quality of life. This is a common psychological tool used in suicide prevention and depression. Even if you don’t suffer from suicidal thoughts or depression, participating in positive activities has been found to help most individuals.

In the next few slides, I’m going to help you set up this app. First you will be asked to deselect the types of activities that you do not like and then choose individuals in your phone’s contact list who you might want to do an activity with in the future. You will have the option in this app to participate in an activity alone, with one other person (Pair) or in a group.

Disclaimer: The information in the application is not intended as a substitute for any type of professional medical services or training and should not be used for such purposes. The information is provided as is and the author does not warrant the accuracy of the information. This information is not meant to diagnose or develop permanent treatment plans for health emergencies, health problems or diseases. If you are in an emergency or life-threatening medical situation, seek medical assistance immediately. Dial emergency number (911 in the USA) for emergency medical services.

External Links: The appearance of external hyperlinks does not constitute endorsement by the United States Department of Defense of the linked websites, or the information, products or services contained therein. The United States Department of Defense does not exercise any editorial control over the information you may find at these locations. All links are provided consistent with the stated purpose of these DoD websites.

Activity suggestions were adopted from: Skills Training Manual for Treating Borderline Personality Disorder by Marsha M. Linehan, 1st Edition (1993), p. 157-159. Copyright Guilford Press. Reprinted with permission of The Guilford Press. As well as MacPhillamy, D. J., & Lewinsohn, P. M. (1982). The pleasant events schedule: Studies on reliability, validity, and scale intercorrelation. Journal of Consulting and Clinical Psychology, 50(3), 363-380.

Learn More

Positive Activity Jackpot is a tool containing research supported techniques to help individuals with depression, suicidal behaviors or those with no mental health issues. By frequently participating in fun, positive activities, individuals are thought to build up a resiliency against various future mental health problems. This app should not take the place of regular mental health treatment or be used exclusively to treat these issues. This application can only augment other treatments. If at any point you feel suicidal please call the crisis care hotline at (800)273-8255.

Positive Activity Jackpot is an application that allows you to choose from a list of over 375 possible activities, have the app choose a random activity for you, or show you activities in your immediate surroundings using augmented reality, or AR, technology. All these activities can be done either alone, in a pair or with a group. This app uses your contacts list to easily invite others to participate either through text, phone, or email. It also lets you post a chosen activity to your social media feeds, such as Facebook or Twitter.

Positive Activity Jackpot is smart; meaning it takes your past activity ratings (you are asked to rate each activity after it is performed) and teaches the app what you generally like and don’t like. While this doesn’t eliminate possible future activities (only you can do that in the Settings tab), it makes it more likely that enjoyable activities will be suggested for you under the Jackpot tab. This app also gives you a lot of personal controls, letting you deselect activities you don’t enjoy or changing possible friends you might like to do an activity with.

Activity suggestions were adapted from: Skills Training Manual for Treating Borderline Personality Disorder by Marsha M. Linehan, 1st Edition (1993), p. 157-159. Copyright Guilford Press. Reprinted with permission of The Guilford Press. As well as MacPhillamy, D. J., & Lewinsohn, P. M. (1982). The pleasant events schedule: Studies on reliability, validity, and scale intercorrelation. Journal of Consulting and Clinical Psychology, 50(3), 363-380.
